Message.Msg: It's the symbolic nature of the fact that BAC can now get back to returning capital to shareholders. The $10 billion buyback is split evenly between preferred and common shares. It is a milestone that BAC needed to get past in order to be able to look forward rather than remain stuck in muck of the past.

Message.Title: BAC declares quarterly dividend
Message.Msg: Bank of America Corporation today announced the Board of Directors declared a regular quarterly cash dividend on Bank of America common stock of $0.01 per share, payable on June 28, 2013 to shareholders of record as of June 7, 2013. The board also declared a regular quarterly cash dividend of $1.75 per share on the 7 percent Cumulative Redeemable Preferred Stock, Series B. The dividend is payable on July 25, 2013 to shareholders of record as of July 11, 2013.

Message.Title: Boston bombing suspect’s family reportedly received $100G from taxpayers
Message.Msg: The accused Boston Marathon bombers' family pulled in more than $100,000 in welfare up until 2012, The Boston Herald reported. The benefits included food stamps, Section 8 housing and stipends, the report said. One person with knowledge of the documents that will be handed over to the House Post Audit and Oversight Committee told the paper, "the breadth of the benefits the family was receiving was stunning."

Topic.Title: WHY DOWN TODAY??

Message.Msg: No real reason other than the finny's continue to experience a lack of luvin' by the market. Besides that, BAC is basically struggling to get/stay north of the ~$12.40 line. Since 2013 began it's tested that level about 6 times, and each time (ultimately) failed. You can see it clearly on the chart. But this ain't so surprising given that prior to 2013 the last time it had been conclusively north of that line was back in May of 2011. So from a longer term point of view what your witnessing is consolidation occurring via the function of time. And I'm okay with this, from a longer term point of view, so long as the company continues to work its comeback execution accordingly. I'll just continue to trade it around a longer term core position.

Message.Title: Any Thoughts?
Message.Msg: Study: Megabanks may disappear By Stephen Gandel, senior editorApril 30, 2013 Consultant calls recently proposed banking regulations such as Brown-Vitter "weapons of mass dissolution." A report about the global banking industry by Boston Consulting Group, which was released on Tuesday, says new regulations and less business will force the big banks to dramatically shrink. Of the 28 global banks the consulting firm looked at, only three -- Goldman Sachs (GS), Deutsche Bank (DB), and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) -- will be able to remain at their current size, according to BCG. The others, which include such banking behemoths as Bank of America (BAC), Barclays (BCS), Citigroup (C), Credit Suisse (CS), and Morgan Stanley (MS), will have to exit businesses, eliminate staffers, and rethink what they do in order to survive

Message.Title: Here is a question for a lawyer to answer. They say homes are toxic investment but then now some prices
Message.Msg: Some homes are now selling higher than they were in 2006 where it peaked. My question is the price of homes toxic when sold to others? Toxic only if we have another crash in home prices again. It is not toxic if home prices never drop. So, just like any investment, it can drop and when it drops it becomes toxic to those who bought it. No one really knows when something you bought will drop or when it will drop.

Message.Title: Pressure buildng up for BAC to go up. This is the logic I lay out.
Message.Msg: 1. Inventory of homes lower. 2. Home prices are recovering. 3. Flippers and investors are buying homes with cash and resold them for higher prices which helps bank owned homes able to sell at higher prices. 4. New home sales are strong with people lining up in lotteries to buy them. This is the first sign of a housing recovery. 5. World economy finally bottomed. 6. If it were not for Obamacare, the job market would have exploded. 7. Loan rates are sill very low. 8. There is no logic that CDO are toxic since at certain time frame they were deemed to be worth what the market accepted. No one knows when home prices will drop or go up. 9. BAC has done a great job of turning the company lean again. 10. The stock cannot be hold too long at these low prices forever. $20 is coming I believe. JMO based on logic.
